information:
As of mid-May 2025, New York Yankees player Aaron Judge's batting average was reported at various points between .402 and .423. On May 17, after a 2-for-4 game, his average reached .414, though a subsequent 0-for-5 game lowered it. By May 18, Judge had accumulated 15 home runs and 41 RBI for the season, leading the league in several offensive categories. An analysis by MLB.com noted that achieving a .414 batting average with over 15 home runs within a team's first 44 games is a rare historical feat, with parallels to seasons by Mickey Mantle in 1956 and Manny Ramirez in 2001.

According to a list of National League batting leaders published on May 18, 2025, Freddie Freeman of the Los Angeles Dodgers was leading with a .375 average. Other top hitters included Will Smith (Los Angeles Dodgers) at .336, Brendan Donovan (St. Louis Cardinals) at .330, and Manny Machado (San Diego Padres) at .323. In the American League, David Alonso of the New York Mets had a team-high batting average of .308 as of May 17. In Triple-A, Chicago Cubs prospect Matt Shaw was reported to be hitting .400 over his last eight games.

The last Major League Baseball player to finish a season with a batting average of .400 or higher was Ted Williams, who hit .406 in 1941. One analysis noted that modern players face challenges in reaching this mark, such as higher strikeout rates; early in the 2025 season, Aaron Judge had 31 strikeouts, whereas Williams had only 27 in his entire 1941 season. Another factor is Batting Average on Balls In Play (BABIP). The major league-wide BABIP in 2025 is .288, compared to .300 in 1930. In 2000, Ichiro Suzuki recorded a .387 batting average but was limited to 105 games due to an injury.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — early-season .400 runs typically cool off over the next 1–2 weeks, and no other hitter is close enough to make a late charge.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Aaron Judge has an average 10–12 game stretch (e.g., ~14–16 hits in ~45–50 AB, ~.300–.350) that pulls his season mark below .400, and no one else climbs from the mid-.300s to .400 by June 1. ESPN’s page shows no player at .400 or higher.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Judge stays hot (roughly .380 over the next ~40–50 AB), benefits from some walks (reducing AB), and lands at or rounds to .400 on ESPN’s page on June 1. Alternatively (depending on how ESPN’s page is interpreted), a recent call-up with limited AB is displayed at .400+.
forecast.rationale:
What matters is who can be at or above .400 on June 1 per ESPN. As of mid-May, Aaron Judge has hovered around .400 (.402–.414 reported; .414 on May 17 before an 0-for-5 on May 18). The NL leader (Freddie Freeman) is around .375, and others are further back, so this is effectively a question about Judge maintaining .400 through the next ~13 days.

Back-of-the-envelope: If Judge is ~.403 with ~155–165 AB now, he’ll likely accumulate ~40–50 more AB by June 1. To remain ≥.400 overall, he roughly needs ~19 hits in 48 AB (~.396) if he’s at ~.403 today; if he’s a bit higher (e.g., ~.410), he needs closer to ~17 in 48 (~.354). Walks (not AB) would help by lowering the denominator. Rounding on ESPN (to three decimals) also helps at the margin (≥.3995 shows as .400).

Base rates and regression: Finishing a season at .400 hasn’t happened since 1941, but being ≥.400 by early June does occur occasionally (e.g., Arraez in 2023). Still, the modal outcome is that a hot start cools over 10–12 games. Judge’s profile (power, higher K rate) is more volatile and typically less BA-stable than a high-contact hitter. League-wide BABIP is lower than historical eras, which also leans against sustained .400. On the other hand, the short horizon (two weeks) makes the bar attainable if he stays hot; needing around .380 or better for ~12 games is within reasonable variance for a star on a heater.

Research assistant highlights that influenced this forecast: Judge’s mid-May .402–.414, his 15 HR/41 RBI pace, NL leader ~.375, and historical/modern context (K rates, BABIP). I discount the assistant’s one apparent misstatement (“David Alonso” on Mets) but the core point—no one besides Judge is close—stands.

Why not higher? Regression to ~.320–.350 over the next ~12 games is the base case; one or two 0-fors quickly pull a .403 season AVG under .400. Also, ESPN’s page typically defaults to “qualified” hitters; if that’s the interpretation, it removes the small-sample path to Yes.

Why not lower? Judge is already essentially at .400, the window is short, rounding can help, and walk-heavy games can preserve the average by limiting AB. A 10–12 game .360–.420 run is well within Judge’s range.

What would move me up: Judge remains ≥.405 through May 24–26; evidence that ESPN’s resolution will count non-qualified players; a stretch of high walk rates reducing AB. What would move me down: Judge dips to ≤.395 by May 22–24; a run of tough opposing pitching/parks; confirmation that only qualified leaders are considered and that no other hitter is within ~.390 by May 25.
